convictionLayer.content: Full CSS architecture for the entire page (7 refinery zones, 12+ component types, 3 transition types, responsive breakpoints). HTML for Perimeter zone (TOC, Complexity Ladder, Prerequisites, Yegge bio) and Intake zone (Mental Model with comparison diagrams and pull quotes). The control-panel component for dark ASCII displays. Comparison-table variant with asymmetric column styling (muted left/present right). Zone-transition system with three types (hard cut, checkpoint, spacing shift).

The refinery cross-section as lived atmosphere, not applied decoration. The Perimeter zone should feel like standing outside an industrial facility reading warning signs — measured, gatekeeping, uncompromising but not hostile. The checkpoint transition into the Intake zone should feel like passing through a gate where the air changes. The Yegge quotes should land as machinery sounds — the "world's biggest fuckin' ant" quote in pull-quote--impact variant with 1.625rem Instrument Serif is the loudest moment in the opening sections.

(1) Solid offset depth (Mechanism #3) — the refinery cross-section is about flatness and cross-sectional honesty; faux-depth via offsets would add playfulness that contradicts the industrial tone. (2) Bento grid for the opening sections — considered a grid layout for the "current state / after this" comparison, but the Perimeter zone demands linear gatekeeping, not modular browsing. Bento will serve the Processing Core (8 roles) in later chunks. (3) Width variation for pull quotes — considered narrowing Yegge's quotes to 60% width with margin-left offset, but decided full-width-within-container gives more authority to his voice. (4) Drop cap on the Yegge section opening — the Perimeter zone is diagnostic, not editorial; reserved drop-cap for the Intake zone's "This is the fundamental shift" paragraph where editorial authority serves destabilization.

The TOC zone labels (PERIMETER, INTAKE, CORE, INFRA, OUTPUT, EXHAUST) create a spatial map of the page that didn't exist in the source content. The reader sees the entire refinery cross-section before entering, which transforms the TOC from navigation into architecture. Also surprised by how much the comparison-table asymmetric styling (muted traditional column vs. warm Gas Town column) reinforces the opposition without adding any words — the CSS IS the argument.

A more dramatic zone transition between Perimeter and Intake — considered a full-bleed dark band with the zone label, but the checkpoint transition type was more honest. Also wanted to add subtle gauge-mark pseudo-elements (small red dashes) at section boundaries for industrial atmosphere, but this would be decorative motion, not structural.

(1) The Intake zone background (--zone-intake: #EDE8DE) bleeds into the page container via negative margins — this works but needs verification that subsequent chunks' zone transitions back to lighter backgrounds don't create jarring breaks. (2) The density arc within this chunk is a gentle crescendo from LOW (ladder) to MEDIUM (tables/quotes), but hasn't yet reached the HIGH density that the Processing Core will demand. The next chunk needs to ramp significantly. (3) The control-panel component works for ASCII art but may need adaptation for the more complex role hierarchy diagrams in Section 3.

discoveryLog: Discovery 1: The conviction brief's opposition (INDUSTRIAL SCALE vs. INDIVIDUAL COMMAND) maps directly to CSS decisions: the comparison-table's asymmetric column styling embodies this tension visually — the "Traditional Dev" column is muted/receding (individual, fading), while the "Gas Town" column is warm/present (factory, arriving). The opposition lives in the background-color delta between table columns.

Discovery 2: R5's "First Component Rule" (the first component sets section tone) became a structural decision: the Complexity Ladder as a dark control-panel hero is the FIRST visual after the header, and it immediately establishes the industrial/diagnostic tone. If the first element had been prose or a callout, the entire Perimeter zone would feel advisory rather than gatekeeping.

Discovery 3: The transition grammar from CD-006 (Smooth/Bridge/Breathing) maps to the refinery metaphor's zone boundaries more precisely than expected. The Perimeter→Intake transition is genuinely a HARD CUT (different domain: credibility → conceptual disruption), while the You Are Here→Who is Yegge transition is a SPACING SHIFT (same domain: reader assessment, different intensity). The transition types aren't just spatial techniques — they encode how the reader's cognitive mode changes at each boundary, exactly as CD-F-025 predicted.
